[[Maryhill School of Theology]] {{small|([[Master of Arts|MA]])}} |website = {{url|web.archive.org/web/20080724192642/http://www.miriam.com.ph|Official website}} }} '''Miriam Palma Defensor Santiago''' (15 June 1945 – 29 September 2016) was a Filipino lawyer, professor, judge, author, and statesman, who served in all three branches of the Philippine government: judicial, executive, and legislative. While never officially assumed the post, she has been recognized posthumously as the "best president the Philippines never had."https://technology.inquirer.net/53051/netizens-agree-miriam-was-the-best-president-the-country-never-had She also worked at the [[United Nations]] while studying abroad. Some of her alma maters are [[University of the Philippines]], [[University of Michigan]], [[Oxford University]], [[Maryhill School of Theology]], [[University of California]], [[Harvard University]], and [[University of Cambridge]]. Defensor Santiago was named one of The 100 Most Powerful Women in the World in 1997 by ''The Australian'' magazine.{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/sen_bio/santiago_bio.asp |title=Senator Miriam Defensor Santiago - Senate of the Philippines |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140723055856/http://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/sen_bio/santiago_bio.asp |archivedate=23 July 2014 |df=dmy }} She was a long-serving [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator of the Republic of the Philippines]]. In 1988, Defensor Santiago was named laureate of the [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] for government service, with a citation ''for bold and moral leadership in cleaning up a graft-ridden government agency.''[http://www.rmaf.org.ph/Awardees/Biography/Biography Santiago Mir.html Biography of Miriam Defensor Santiago], The Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation; retrieved 7 December 2006.{{cite web|url=http://atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/DI13Ae02.html|title=Asia Times|accessdate=15 April 2016}}http://www.fnfasia.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1611:former-fnf-fellowship-student-to-receive-ramon-magsaysay-award{{dead link|date=September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rmaf.org.ph/newrmaf/main/awardees/awardee/profile/177|title=Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation - Awardees|author=Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation|work=RMAF|accessdate=15 April 2016}} She ran in the [[Philippine presidential election, 1992|1992 presidential elections]] but was controversially defeated.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/13/world/anti-corruption-campaigner-and-general-lead-in-early-philippine-returns.html|title=Anti-Corruption Campaigner and General Lead in Early Philippine Returns|date=13 May 1992|work=The New York Times|accessdate=15 April 2016}} In 2012, Defensor Santiago became the first Filipina and the first Asian from a developing country to be elected a judge of the [[International Criminal Court]].{{cite web|title=Delivering on the promise of a fair, effective and independent Court > Election of ICC and ASP Officials > Judges|url=http://www.iccnow.org/?mod=electionjudges|work=Coalition for the International Criminal Court|publisher=Coalition for the International Criminal Court|accessdate=6 June 2013}}{{cite web|title=PRESS STATEMENT ON SENATOR SANTIAGO'S ELECTION AS ICC JUDGE|url=http://www.senate.gov.ph/press_release/2011/1213_revilla1.asp|work=Senate Press Releases|publisher=Senate of the Philippines|accessdate=6 June 2013|date=13 December 2011}} She later resigned the post, citing [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], which turned out to be [[lung cancer]].Ayee Macaraig. [http://www.rappler.com/nation/59531-miriam-resigns-icc-judge It's final: Miriam steps down as ICC judge], Rappler.com; retrieved 8 February 2015.Ayee Macaraig. [http://www.rappler.com/nation/62172-miriam-santiago-lung-cancer "Miriam Santiago: I have lung cancer"]. Rappler.com; retrieved 25 September 2014. In 2016, she became part of the International Advisory Council of the [[International Development Law Organization]] (IDLO), an intergovernmental body that promotes the rule of law.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/01/23/1545386/miriam-join-bill-gates-elite-law-group|title=Miriam to join Bill Gates in elite law group|work=philstar.com|date=23 January 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.idlo.int/about-idlo/our-people|title=Our People - IDLO|publisher=}} Defensor Santiago served three terms in the Philippine Senate. On 13 October 2015, Defensor Santiago [[Miriam Defensor Santiago presidential campaign, 2016|declared her candidacy]] for [[President of the Philippines]] in the [[Philippine presidential election, 2016|2016 elections]] after her doctors from the United States declared her cancer 'stable' and 'receded', but lost in the elections. Defensor Santiago was known as the '''Dragon Lady''', the '''Platinum Lady''', the '''Incorruptible Lady''', the '''Tiger Lady''', and most popularly, the '''Iron Lady of Asia'''. She is colloquially known in Philippine pop culture as simply '''Miriam''' or '''MDS'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.filipiknow.net/interesting-facts-about-miriam-defensor-santiago/|title=15 Surprising Things You Didn't Know About Miriam Defensor-Santiago|date=5 July 2014|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hngn.com/articles/139826/20151013/philippines-iron-lady-of-asia-miriam-santiago-runs-for-president-after-surviving-cancer.htm|title=Philippines: 'Iron Lady Of Asia' Miriam Santiago Runs For President After Surviving Cancer|work=Headlines & Global News|date=13 October 2015}} ==Early life and education== Defensor Santiago was born '''Miriam Palma Defensor''' in [[Iloilo City]], to Benjamin Defensor, a local judge, and Dimpna Palma, a schoolteacher. She was the eldest of seven children. She graduated [[valedictorian]] in grade school, high school, undergraduate school.{{cite book|last=Defensor Santiago|first=Miriam|title=Inventing Myself|publisher=New Day Publishers of the Christian Literature Society of the Philippines, Inc.|date=1994|isbn=971-10-0552-2|page=10}} She graduated high school in [[Iloilo Provincial High School]] (now [[Iloilo National High School]]) and served as the Editor-in-Chief (EIC) of the said high school's student publication "[[The Ilonggo]]". In 1965, Defensor Santiago graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[political science]], ''[[magna cum laude]]'' from the [[University of the Philippines Visayas]]. After graduation, she was elected to the [[Pi Gamma Mu]] and [[Phi Kappa Phi]] honor societies.{{cite web|url=http://www.uprotc.org/directory/corps-sponsors/miriam-defensor-santiago.html|title=Miriam Defensor-Santiago|author=JA Media Solutions, Inc. December 2009|work=University of the Philippines - Reserve Officers' Training Corps|accessdate=15 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512182434/http://www.uprotc.org/directory/corps-sponsors/miriam-defensor-santiago.html|archivedate=12 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} She proceeded to the [[University of the Philippines College of Law]]. There, she was champion in numerous oratorical contests and debates. She became the first female editor of the student newspaper, ''[[The Philippine Collegian]]'', and was twice appointed ROTC muse.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1370&dat=19970719&id=yJgVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9woEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3811,1905778|title=Manila Standard - Google News Archive Search|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://miriam.com.ph/newsblog/about|title=About|work=Miriam Defensor Santiago|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812085435/http://miriam.com.ph/newsblog/about/|archivedate=12 August 2014|df=dmy-all}} She graduated [[Bachelor of Laws]], ''[[cum laude]]'', from the [[University of the Philippines College of Law]] in [[University of the Philippines Diliman|Diliman]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Defensor Santiago went on a fellowship to the [[United States]], and earned the degrees [[Master of Laws]] and [[Doctor of Juridical Science]] degrees at the [[University of Michigan, Ann Arbor]]. She finished both degrees in a period of only one and a half years.{{cite web|url=http://dfa.gov.ph/main/index.php/newsroom/dmds-candidature/dr-miriam-defensor-santiago-cv |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219134533/http://dfa.gov.ph/main/index.php/newsroom/dmds-candidature/dr-miriam-defensor-santiago-cv |archivedate=19 December 2011 |df=dmy }} Following school she took a position as special assistant to the justice secretary. She also taught [[political science]] at the [[Trinity University of Asia]]. She was law professor at the [[University of the Philippines Diliman]], teaching evening classes for some ten years.{{cite web|url=http://www.uprotc.org/1969/directory/corps-sponsors/miriam-defensor-santiago.html|title=Miriam Defensor-Santiago|author=JA Media Solutions, Inc. December 2009|work=University of the Philippines - Reserve Officers' Training Corps|accessdate=15 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508025426/http://www.uprotc.org/1969/directory/corps-sponsors/miriam-defensor-santiago.html|archivedate=8 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/203779/maid-miriam-and-pretty-morales|title=Maid Miriam and pretty Morales|first=Ramon|last=Tulfo|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}} She has studied at several universities, including [[Oxford]] and [[Harvard]] law summer schools; [[Cambridge]]; and [[The Hague Academy of International Law]]. She earned the degree Master of religious studies (without thesis) at the [[Maryhill School of Theology]]. In Oxford, she was a research fellow at St. Hilda's College and also took a summer program in law at St. Edmund's Hall. At Cambridge, she was a research fellow at the Lauterpacht Research Centre for International Law. ==Department of Justice career== She became a special assistant to the Secretary of Justice for ten years after her higher studies abroad. At a young age, she became a legal officer to the United Nations afterwards due to her constitutional and international law knowledge and experience.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} ==United Nations career== Defensor Santiago served as Legal Officer of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees at Geneva, Switzerland. She was assigned to the Conferences and Treaties Section. She became skilled at treaty negotiation and drafting. She resigned her position when her father in the Philippines developed prostate cancer.{{cite book |last= Defensor Santiago|first= Miriam |title= Inventing Myself |publisher= New Day Publishers of the Christian Literature Society of the Philippines, Inc. |date= 1994|isbn= 971-10-0552-2 |page = 82.}} ==Judge during martial Law== Defensor Santiago was appointed judge of the Regional Trial Court (RTC) of Quezon City, Metro Manila by President Ferdinand Marcos. She was the youngest judge appointed to Metro Manila, and exempted from the practice of first serving as a judge outside Metro Manila. As a RTC judge, she quickly proclaimed a "no postponement" policy. At that time, cases were tried in segments that were usually a month apart, resulting in trials that took years to finish. Lawyers were prone to seek postponement of trial. As a result, trial judges scheduled ten or fifteen cases a day, so that they could make up for cases postponed. Defensor Santiago scheduled only five cases a day, heard each case, and disposed of the highest number of cases in her first year in office. {{citaiton needed|date=July 2018}} Defensor Santiago became nationally famous when she issued perhaps the first decision to rule against martial law. At that time, alleged illegal public assemblies were declared as crimes and were punishable by death. {{citation needed|date=July 2018}} A large group of activist students from the University of the Philippines and Ateneo, as well as activists in the film industry, staged a rally in a central business district, and denounced the First Lady for her excesses. To retaliate, Marcos issued a Preventive Detention Action order which authorized the military to hold suspects indefinitely, without bail. The students faced the dire prospect of missing their final exams and, for many of them, missing graduation. Defensor Santiago suspended hearings on all other pending cases, and conducted whole-day trials. In the end, she ordered the military to allow the students to post bail. After promulgating her decision at the end of the day, Defensor Santiago drove herself to the state university, where she was teaching law. The Philippine Jaycees, the Philippine Lions, and the YMCA Philippines all gave her awards for judicial excellence. ==Immigration Commissioner== After martial law, in 1988, President [[Corazon Aquino]] appointed Defensor Santiago as commissioner of the [[Bureau of Immigration (Philippines)|Bureau of Immigration and Deportation]]. At that time, the BID was one of the most corrupt government agencies in Southeast Asia. Defensor Santiago declared the Philippines as "the fake passport capital of the world", and directed raids against criminal syndicates, including the Yakuza. She filled the CID detention center with alien criminals, and ordered construction of another detention center. She extended to legal aliens protection from widespread extortion by requesting President Aquino to issue an executive order that authorized the "alien legalization program".{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/26/world/manila-journal-battling-the-culture-of-corruption-day-by-day.html?scp=7&sq=miriam%20defensor%20santiago&st=cse|title=Manila Journal; Battling the 'Culture of Corruption' Day by Day|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=26 May 1988|accessdate=3 June 2013}} She received serious death threats, but proclaimed: "I eat death threats for breakfast".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/10/world/a-sharp-tongue-propels-a-philippine-candidate.html?scp=4&sq=miriam%20defensor%20santiago&st=cse|work=The New York Times|title=A Sharp Tongue Propels A Philippine Candidate|date=10 May 1992}} A member of the House of Representatives, Laguna Rep. Nereo Joaquin, delivered a privilege speech in 1992 and denounced her raids against pedophile communities in Central Luzon run by alien pedophiles. Defensor Santiago responded by calling him "fungus face".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/10/world/a-sharp-tongue-propels-a-philippine-candidate.html?scp=6&sq=miriam%20defensor%20santiago&st=cse|title=A Sharp Tongue Propels A Philippine Candidate|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=10 May 1992|accessdate=13 March 2011}} The Rockefeller Foundation named her a laureate of the Magsaysay Award for government service – "for bold and moral leadership in cleaning up a graft-ridden government agency." ==Agrarian Reform Secretary== President Corazon Aquino promoted Defensor Santiago to member of her cabinet, as secretary of the [[Department of Agrarian Reform (Philippines)|Secretary of Agrarian Reform]].{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov.ph |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527115514/http://www.senate.gov.ph/ |archivedate=27 May 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://2010.pinoyvote.info/senatoriables/miriam-defensor-santiago|title=Miriam Defensor-Santiago profile|publisher=2010.pinoyvote.info|accessdate=13 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721231246/http://2010.pinoyvote.info/senatoriables/miriam-defensor-santiago/|archivedate=21 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} Under a controversial law passed by Congress and signed by President Aquino, all agricultural landholdings were taken by the government and divided among the farmers. Each landowner was allowed to keep only five hectares, and each farmer received three hectares. Payment was in bonds of the Land Bank. To subvert the law, big landowners applied for conversion of the classification of their land as agricultural, to classification as commercial, residential, or industrial. The process became the widespread "conversion scandal of agrarian reform". The DAR officials themselves were the biggest culprits, because they sold conversion permits for bribes on a market rate set at certain amounts per hectare involved in the conversion. Defensor Santiago stopped the conversion scandal, and appeased the landowners by enhancing the incentives for voluntary offers by the landowners for the sale of their landholdings, which entitled them to an additional five percent cash payment. When asked if the hacienda belonging to the president's family should be covered by agrarian reform, Defensor Santiago replied that the family's hacienda should be distributed among the farmers. Shortly thereafter President Aquino accepted Defensor Santiago's resignation.{{cite web|url=http://miriam.com.ph/aboutmiriam.php|title=About Miriam - The Official Website of Miriam Defensor Santiago|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430164032/http://miriam.com.ph/aboutmiriam.php|archivedate=30 April 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==1992 presidential elections== {{main|Philippine presidential election, 1992}} Defensor Santiago organized the [[People's Reform Party]] (PRP) and ran with a senatorial ticket during the 1992 presidential campaign. [[Ramon Magsaysay Jr.]] was her running mate. While campaigning on 28 April 1991, she was severely injured in car crash,[http://www.miriam.com.ph/aboutmiriam.php About Miriam] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717033018/http://miriam.com.ph/aboutmiriam.php |date=17 July 2014 }}, Defensor Santiago's official website which she claimed was an assassination attempt.[http://miriam.com.ph/newsblog/2010/11/30/the-philippine-senates-demi-moore/ THE PHILIPPINE SENATE'S "DEMI MOORE"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208223729/http://miriam.com.ph/newsblog/2010/11/30/the-philippine-senates-demi-moore/ |date=8 February 2015 }}, Defensor Santiago's official website She was wearing a white bush jacket which became splattered with blood that gushed from a wound to her head. On orders of President Aquino, she was airlifted from Tarlac to a Manila hospital. She underwent surgery on the jaw, and at one point a Catholic priest administered the last rites of the dying. Two months later, she was back on the campaign trail. Defensor Santiago has been dubbed as "The Iron Lady of Asia" and the "Dragon Lady" due to her scathing but bold eloquence both in leadership and writing. She cites physicist [[Marie Curie]] and former British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] as her major influences throughout her political career, with Thatcher praising her for her book ''Cutting Edge'' during their meeting while the Prime Minister visited the Philippines.{{cite news | url=http://www.spot.ph/feed/rss/index.php/newsfeatures/the-latest-news-features/63969/10-facts-miriam-defensor-santiago | title=10 Surprising Things You Didn't Know About Miriam Defensor Santiago | work=Spot.PH | publisher=[[Summit Media]] | date=October 15, 2015 | accessdate=29 September 2016}} Defensor Santiago was leading the canvassing of votes for the first five days. Following a string of power outages, the tabulation concluded, and Ramos was declared president-elect. Defensor Santiago filed a protest before the Supreme Court as electoral tribunal, citing the power outages during the counting of votes as evidence of massive fraud. Her election protest was eventually dismissed on a technicality.{{cite web|last=Shenon|first=Philip|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10617F835540C778DDDAC0894DA494D81&scp=27&sq=miriam%20defensor%20santiago&st=cse|title=Front-Runners Are Nip and Tuck As Philippine Returns Trickle In|location=Philippines |publisher=Select.nytimes.com|date=14 May 1992|accessdate=13 March 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/24/world/power-failures-slow-philippine-vote-count-and-feed-suspicions-of-fraud.html?scp=9&sq=miriam%20defensor%20santiago&st=cse|title=Power Failures Slow Philippine Vote Count|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=24 May 1992|accessdate=13 March 2011}} The public outrage over the presidential results prompted ''Newsweek'' to feature her and her rival on the cover with the question: "Was the Election Fair?" In another cover story, ''Philippines Free Press'' magazine asked: "Who's the Real President?". The quote, 'Miriam won in the elections but lost in the counting' was popularized by the masses. ==Senator== ===First term, 1995–2001=== Defensor Santiago was first elected senator in 1995. In 1997, her presidential rival [[Fidel Ramos]] initiated a "people's campaign" for an infinite presidential term. Defensor Santiago harshly criticized Ramos' campaign and went to court. In a landmark case, ''Defensor Santiago vs COMELEC'', she won and preserved the people's mandate for term limits. She again ran for president in the [[Philippine presidential election, 1998|1998 presidential elections]], with running-mate [[Francisco Tatad]], but lost amidst heavy propaganda concerning her mental health, which was later proven false."Senator Miriam Defensor Santiago - Senate of the Philippines". {{cite web|url=http://www.Senate.gov.ph |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527115514/http://www.senate.gov.ph/ |archivedate=27 May 2014 |df=dmy }}; retrieved 13 March 2011. She was one of the few senators who were against the opening of the brown envelope during the impeachment trial of then-President [[Joseph Estrada]], who was her foe in the 1998 presidential elections. She said afterwards:{{quote|At that time, I wanted to apply the rules of court technically. Since there is no allegation of wrongdoing in connection with the notorious second envelope, I voted that we should not open the second envelope until and after the complaint had already been amended [...] I was among those demonized because I voted against the opening of the second envelope – ''dahil ang paniwala ng taong bayan, kung ayaw namin buksan ang'' second envelope ''na 'yan, may tinatago kami''. (translation from Filipino: because in the belief of the masses if we don't want to open the envelope, then we are hiding something.)}}Estrada was ousted in the [[Second EDSA Revolution]] in 2001, but was sent free in 2007 by President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] who was persuaded by senator [[Mar Roxas]]. Defensor Santiago lost re-election to the senate in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/245548/news/nation/miriam-learn-from-erap-trial-and-let-public-see-evidence|title=Miriam: Learn from Erap trial and let public see evidence|publisher=gmanetwork.com|accessdate=29 September 2016}} ===Second and third term, 2004–2016=== {{refimprove section|date=September 2016}} Defensor Santiago ran for senator in 2004 and was elected. She focused on creating significant laws that changed the country as a whole. She ran again for senator in 2010 and won. During her three terms, she served as chair mostly of the foreign relations committee and the constitutional amendments committee. She was elected as official candidate of her party [[People's Reform Party]], serving also as chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Commission on Appointments. She exposed and named numerous ''jueteng'' (illegal gambling) lords and illegal-logging lords throughout her terms.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In 2011, Defensor Santiago was elected as a judge of the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC) which hears cases against humanity for former heads of state. She was the first Asian from a third world country to be elected to such a post. She resigned in 2014 after being diagnosed with lung cancer. She was one of the senators who backed Supreme Court Chief Justice Renato Corona during his impeachment trial; he was ultimately impeached due to corruption. In December 2012, she exposed that the Senate president, [[Juan Ponce Enrile]], used Senate funds to give away as cash gifts. Every senator, except Defensor Santiago and two others, received 2 million pesos as a chunk of the Filipino population lived in poverty. This led to the [[Priority Development Assistance Fund scandal]], which put the Senate president behind bars with charges of plunder. Defensor Santiago's live Senate hearings in the case led to public outrage and support for Defensor Santiago's call to abolish the pork-barrel system. She was the first Filipino elected as a commissioner for the [[International Development Law Organization]] (IDLO) in 2016. Her role in the organization was advisory to the international law community.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/01/23/1545386/miriam-join-bill-gates-elite-law-group|title=Miriam to join Bill Gates in elite law group|first=Marvin|last=Sy|website=PhilStar.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} ===Select laws authored=== The many laws that Defensor Santiago authored include: *Reproductive Health Act of 2012, which instills reproductive health education throughout the nation, and was backed by the majority of the population while criticized by religious institutions in the predominantly Roman Catholic country.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/326013/congress-passes-rh-bill|title=Congress passes RH bill|author1=Cathy C. Yamsuan|author2=Christian V. Esguerra|author3=Leila B. Salaverria|accessdate=15 April 2016}} *Sin Tax Law, which improved the taxation of the country and led to the economic revolutions that bolstered Philippine shares.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/293374/use-my-version-of-sin-tax-bill-santiago-urges-peers|title=Use my version of sin tax bill, Santiago urges peers|first=Cathy|last=Yamsuan|accessdate=15 April 2016}} *Climate Change Act of 2009, which mandated the entire nation to become a bastion for climate change responsiveness, mitigation, adaptation, and management.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/473664/senate-passes-climate-change-act-final-reading|title=Senate passes Climate Change Act on final reading|work=philstar.com|accessdate=15 April 2016}} *Renewable Energy Act of 2008, which mandated the government to shift the energy source of the country from coal and oil into solar, wind, and other renewable sources – this became the foundation for the establishment of numerous wind and solar plants in the country which made the Philippines the 'Wind Energy Capital of Southeast Asia'.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20071105-98990/Greenpeace_presses_passage_of_renewable_energy_bill |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213092121/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20071105-98990/Greenpeace_presses_passage_of_renewable_energy_bill |archivedate=13 December 2014 |df=dmy }} *Philippine Act on Crimes Against International Humanitarian Law, which safeguarded human rights in the entire nation.{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ph/2009/12/11/republic-act-no-9851/|title=Republic Act No. 9851|work=Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines|accessdate=15 April 2016}} *Magna Carta of Women, which protected the rights of women in the country.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/207867/santiago-pia-cayetano-smell-victory-for-rh-bill|title=Santiago, Pia Cayetano smell victory for RH bill|accessdate=15 April 2016}} *Unified Student Financial Assistance System for Tertiary Education (Unifast) Act, which enhanced the educational system in the country, paving way for the intellectual revolution in urban and rural areas.{{cite web|url=http://senate.gov.ph/lis/bill_res.aspx?congress=16&q=SBN-2679|title=16th Congress - Senate Bill No. 2679 - Senate of the Philippines|publisher=}} *Cybercrime Act of 2012, which protected the nation and its people from cybercrimes which infested the country's cyberspace.{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ph/2012/09/12/republic-act-no-10175|title=Republic Act No. 10175|work=Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines|accessdate=15 April 2016}} *Department of Information and Communication Technology Act, which established the Department of Information and Communication Technology for better information dissemination and better internet speed in the country *Archipelagic Baselines Act of 2009, which became one of the major basises for the country's claims on maritime sovereignty, including the [[West Philippine Sea]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ph/2009/03/10/republic-act-no-9522/|title=Republic Act No. 9522|work=Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines|accessdate=15 April 2016}} ==2016 Presidential Elections== In October 2015, Defensor Santiago announced her intention to run in the [[Philippine presidential election, 2016|2016 Philippine presidential elections]] after her cancer was deemed 'stable' and 'receded' by doctors from the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/10/13/1510285/miriam-run-president|title=Miriam to run for president|work=philstar.com|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/miriam-wades-in/223725/|title=Miriam wades in - The Manila Times Online|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}} She later confirmed that Senator [[Bongbong Marcos]] would serve as her running mate for [[Vice President of the Philippines|vice president]]. Her campaign focused on the youth sector for which she heavily advocated, making use of social media. She was a landslide winner in numerous polls conducted in various public and private universities and colleges in the country. Despite this, she lost in the elections.{{cite news|last1=Hegina|first1=Aries Joseph|title=Miriam Santiago confirms Bongbong Marcos is her vice president|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/731184/miriam-santiago-confirms-bongbong-marcos-is-her-veep|accessdate=15 October 2015|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=15 October 2015}} Defensor Santiago was subsequently called "the greatest president we never had",{{cite news | author=Royandoyan, Ramon H. | title=Netizens agree: Miriam was the best president the country never had | url=http://technology.inquirer.net/53051/netizens-agree-miriam-was-the-best-president-the-country-never-had | work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] | publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer, Inc. | date=September 30, 2016 | accessdate=October 5, 2016 }}{{cite news | author=Elemia, Camille | title=Senators: Miriam a big loss, 'best president we never had' | url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147687-senate-mourns-miriam-santiago-death | work=[[Rappler]] | publisher=Rappler, Inc. | date=September 29, 2016 | accessdate=October 5, 2016 }} a title which had been associated with her prior to her presidential run.{{cite news | title=10 Awesome Presidents We Never Had | url=http://www.spot.ph/newsfeatures/the-latest-news-features/61846/10-awesome-presidents-we-never-had | work=Spot.PH | publisher=[[Summit Media]] | date=8 April 2015 | access-date=5 October 2016 }} ==Retirement== Even after retirement, Defensor Santiago continued to advocate the passage of many bills for the nation while in her [[Quezon City]] home. A few of these include: the anti-dynasty bill; an act institutionalizing an age-appropriate curriculum to prevent the abduction, exploitation, and sexual abuse of children; anti-epal bill; freedom of information bill; and the magna carta for Philippine internet freedom.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Before her death, various groups in the country have been lauding her to join the candidacy for the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] Secretary-General post where the elected Secretary-General will be positioned for 2018. Among other candidates for the position are AirAsia chief Tony Fernandes of Malaysia and an unstated representative from Brunei, which is the lead country for 2018–2022 according to tradition.{{cite web|url=http://investvine.com/airasia-chiefs-futile-bid-to-become-asean-secretary-general/|title=AirAsia chief's futile to become ASEAN Secretary-General|first=Arno|last=Maierbrugger|date=17 August 2015|publisher=}} She was awarded as a "Distinguished Icon of Legal Excellence and Public Service" by the [[University of the Philippines]] in September 2016,{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/08/26/1617338/morales-named-icon-legal-excellence-public-service|title=Morales named icon of legal excellence, public service|publisher=philstar.com|access-date=30 September 2016}} and posthumously the "PUP Online Personality of the Year Award" by the [[Polytechnic University of the Philippines]] in November 2016.{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/11/29/16/miriam-defensor-santiago-is-pups-online-personality-of-the-year|title=Miriam Defensor Santiago is PUP's 'Online Personality of the Year'|first=ABS-CBN|last=News|website=ABS-CBN.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} ===Death=== [[File:0165jfMedia coverage Wake ceremonies Cubao Cathedral Quezon Cityfvf 07.jpg|thumb|Wake of Miriam Defensor Santiago at the Cubao Cathedral.]] At the age of 71, Defensor Santiago died in her sleep at exactly 8:52 a.m. on 29 September 2016 while she was confined at the [[St. Luke's Medical Center - Global City|St. Luke's Medical Center]] in [[Taguig]] from [[lung cancer]]; several reports cited that Defensor Santiago died in her residence in La Vista Subdivision, [[Quezon City]].{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/820199/miriam-defensor-santiago-passes-away-at-71|title=Miriam Defensor-Santiago passes away at 71|first=Juliet Javellana, Maila|last=Ager|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/09/29/16/miriam-defensor-santiago-passes-away|title=Miriam Defensor Santiago passes away|publisher=ABS-CBN}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/miriam-defensor-santiago-a-shining-light-in-ph-politics-malacanang/|title=Miriam Defensor-Santiago, a "shining light" in PH politics – Malacañang|publisher=[[Manila Bulletin]]|date=September 29, 2016|accessdate=September 29, 2016}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Santiago's last words according to her husband were, "I accept this. I do not want to do anything heroic."https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/820213/miriams-last-words-i-accept-this-i-dont-want-to-do-anything-heroic While her last wish was to remain only in the memory of her own family.https://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/03/16/family-bares-miriam-santiagos-last-wish Her body [[lying in state|lay in state]] at the Cathedral Grottos of the [[Cubao Cathedral|Immaculate Conception Cathedral]] in [[Cubao]] the following day.{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/583404/news/nation/miriam-s-wake-a-sea-of-red-as-supporters-pay-last-respects|title=Miriam's wake a sea of red as supporters pay last respects |work=[[GMA Network]]|date=30 September 2016|accessdate=1 October 2016}} Following a Catholic [[Requiem|funeral Mass]], she was interred at the Loyola Memorial Park in [[Marikina]] on 2 October, beside the tomb of her son Alexander, who died in 2003.{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147754-santiago-burial-october-2-marikina |title=Miriam Defensor Santiago to be buried on October 2 in Marikina |work=[[Rappler]]|date=29 September 2016|accessdate=1 October 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Pasion|first1=Patty|title=Miriam Defensor Santiago laid to rest|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147939-miriam-defensor-santiago-buried|accessdate=2 October 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=2 October 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://kickerdaily.com/posts/2016/09/granting-wish-santiago-will-be-buried-beside-her-son/ |title=Granting her wish, Santiago will be buried beside her son |author=San Jose, Clarissa E. |work=Kicker Daily News|date=29 September 2016|accessdate=1 October 2016}} Santiago's hometown, [[Iloilo City]], declared a day of mourning for Santiagohttps://news.abs-cbn.com/news/09/29/16/iloilo-city-declares-day-of-mourning-for-miriam-santiago and flew the Philippine flag half-mast from September 9 to October 17, 2016. The local government said in an official statement that Santiago 'brought pride and honor to all Ilonggos'.http://mindanao.politics.com.ph/iloilo-to-fly-flag-at-half-mast-for-miriam-till-oct-7/ In June 2017, members of the [[People's Reform Party|Youth Reform Movement]] lobbied for the posthumous awarding of the [[Quezon Service Cross]] to Defensor Santiago. In September 2017, Senator [[Grace Poe]], her freedom of information (FOI) ally and 2016 presidential rival, nominated Defensor Santiago to be awarded the Quezon Service Cross, the highest honor in the entire Republic, subject for approval of both houses of Congress and by President [[Rodrigo Duterte]], who was also her presidential rival. On the same month, Senator [[Sonny Angara]], who considers Defensor Santiago as his mentor, followed suit by filing another resolution nominating Defensor Santiago to become a laureate of the prestigious Quezon Service Cross, just days before Defensor Santiago's first death anniversary on September 29. The Senate expressed its full intent to confer Defensor Santiago the award.{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/09/26/17/senators-nominate-miriam-defensor-santiago-for-highest-civil-service-award-days-before-death-anniversary|title=Senators nominate Miriam Defensor Santiago for highest civil service award days before death anniversary|first=ABS-CBN|last=News|website=ABS-CBN.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} The president, through the Presidential Palace, welcomed the proposal to bestow the award to Santiago once both houses of Congress have ratified the document conferring such award.{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/09/28/17/palace-welcomes-proposal-granting-highest-civil-service-award-for-miriam|title=Palace welcomes proposal granting highest civil service award for Miriam|first=Dharel Placido, ABS-CBN|last=News|website=ABS-CBN.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} The House of Representatives is the only body left that has yet to express its intent to bestow the award to Defensor Santiago. Most members of the House are against Defensor Santiago's anti-political dynasty bill which she introduced in Congress. Santiago's bill is backed by the Constitution itself, where it mandates both chambers of Congress to enact such a law.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/627525/palace-supports-senators-call-to-honor-miriam-highest-civilian-award/story/|title=Palace supports senators' call to honor Miriam highest civilian award|website=GMANetwork.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} On December 5, 2017, the president officially nominated Defensor Santiago for the award, awaiting concurrence of both chambers of Congress to officially bestow the award. Santiago is the sixth person and the first and only woman to be nominated for the award. If bestowed the award, she would be the sixth person to be immortalized in the 69-year old national roster.{{cite web|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/190505-miriam-santiago-quezon-service-cross-nomination-duterte|title=Duterte nominates Miriam Santiago for Quezon Service Cross|website=Rappler.com|access-date=16 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/12/06/17/duterte-nominates-miriam-santiago-for-highest-civil-service-award|title=Duterte nominates Miriam Santiago for highest civil service award|first=Dharel Placido, ABS-CBN|last=News|website=ABS-CBN.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} In December 11, 2017, the Senate approved the bestowing of the award to Defensor Santiago.{{cite web|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/191060-senate-resolution-quezon-service-cross-miriam-defensor-santiago|title=Senate approves highest civilian award for Miriam Santiago|website=Rappler.com|access-date=16 December 2017}} In February 20, 2018, the House of Representatives approved the bestowing of the award to Defensor Santiago. Once the symbolic conferring of the award to is made by the President, Santiago will officially be the sixth person and first woman to be enthroned in the country's highest accolade.http://www.interaksyon.com/house-joins-senate-in-endorsing-quezon-service-cross-for-miriam-santiago/ ==Political positions== {{BLP sources section|date=September 2016}} ===Domestic policy=== ====Federalism==== {{see also|Federalism in the Philippines}} Santiago is not in favor of Federalism, stating in one interview that, "The masses and the entire electorate will not choose who the president will be. We leave that choice to a group of politicians, and we know how those politicians act. Mostly, their actions are always attended by corruption."{{cite web |last1=Defensor-Santiago |first1=Miriam |title=Press Release |url=http://www.senate.gov.ph/press_release/2015/0325_santiago3.asp |website=Senate of the Philippines |publisher=Office of Senator Miriam Defensor-Santiago |accessdate=3 July 2018}} ====Charter change==== {{see also|Constitutional reform in the Philippines}} {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2017}} Defensor Santiago was in favor of amending the [[Constitution of the Philippines]] to enhance foreign investments in the country and to mandate that all high posts in government (senator, congressperson, president, vice president, governor, mayor, vice mayor, secretaries, undersecretaries, etc.) should have additional qualifications which are 'a college graduate' and must pass a duly-accredited government examination. Numerous politicians in the country are only high school or elementary graduates, and most college graduate officials have never passed the Civil Service Examination for Professionals (CSE-P). She argues that positions in government like administrative assistant must pass the CSE-P as a qualification, 'why not higher posts too?'. ====Anti-political dynasty==== Defensor Santiago was the principal author of the ''Anti-Dynasty Bill'' in the Senate and had been pushing for its immediate passage in Congress for more than a decade. Unfortunately, most of the congresspersons in the House of Representatives, which are the bulk of Filipino politicians, are not in favor of its passage because they are part of political dynasties. {{citation needed|date=July 2018}} ====West Philippine Sea dispute==== {{see also|Territorial disputes in the South China Sea}} She stressed during a live debate that the [[West Philippine Sea]] is a sovereign territory of the Philippines and that the country should have a better military and police force and assets and should prioritize enhancing ties with allied nations, especially in the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN). She was one of the international law experts who criticized China and aided in the Philippine case against China. The case was won by the Philippines in 2016. Despite this, China still does not recognize the ruling.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} ====Mindanao==== {{see also|Moro conflict}} Defensor Santiago was against the [[Bangsamoro Basic Law]], saying it is unconstitutional because it specifies that Bangsamoro will become a 'sub-state' of the republic which is illegal under the law. She prefers a more constitutional form of the Bangsamoro Basic Law which does not create a 'sub-state' government.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} ====North Borneo dispute==== {{see also|North Borneo dispute}} Defensor Santiago was in favor of appointing a third-party to conduct under international law "inquiry and fact-finding" to resolve the [[North Borneo dispute]], where the third-party is approved by both the national governments of Malaysia and the Philippines. She cited the 1907 Hague Convention for the Pacific Settlement of Disputes as motivator of her legal position. She said that this can end the dispute as it did in the 1981 involvement of mercenaries in an invasion of the Seychelles, the 1987 use of chemical weapons in the Gulf War between Iran and Iraq, and the 1988 destruction of Korean Air Lines Boeing 747. She said that since no transfer of sovereignty was involved in the 1878 Deed, no transfer of sovereignty has ever passed to Malaysia. She added that the Philippines has never abandoned its claim over eastern Sabah.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/299478/news/nation/miriam-seeks-third-party-inquiry-on-sabah-crisis|title=Miriam seeks third-party inquiry on Sabah crisis|publisher=}} ===Social policy=== ====Divorce==== Defensor Santiago publicly advocated for the passage of a divorce law in the Philippines, saying, "Why would you force [couples] to be together if they want to kill each other by mere sight?" With respect to her position on divorce, she clarified that it should be restricted on two grounds: "an attempt on the life of the spouse by the other" and "when one spouse is already living with another person, that is adultery or [[concubinage]]." In the [[Philippine presidential election, 2016|2016 Presidential campaign]], despite being unable to attend the second debate citing health concerns, she reiterated on [[Twitter]] her position on divorce,{{cite news |url=http://interaksyon.com/article/50813/sen--miriam-favors-divorce-only-on-two-grounds |title=Sen. Miriam favors divorce only on two grounds |author=Reyes, Karl John C. |website=Interaksyon |date=19 December 2012 |access-date=8 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825203026/http://interaksyon.com/article/50813/sen--miriam-favors-divorce-only-on-two-grounds |archivedate=25 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }} leaving her as the only presidential candidate to favor its legislation.{{cite news|last1=Rodriguez|first1=Fritzie|title=Presidential bets on RH, divorce, and LGBT rights|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/123546-presidential-bet-gender-equality|access-date=17 February 2017|publisher=[[Rappler]]|date=25 February 2016}} ====Abortion and contraception==== Defensor Santiago took a critical perspective of [[abortion]] and supports maintaining laws against it: "No to abortion, never. I am a very avid supporter of RH [Reproductive Health] Law, but I will definitely fight to the death against abortion as a lawyer, not necessarily as a religious person. I equate it properly with the crime of murder."{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/12/19/12/miriam-yes-divorce-law-no-abortion |title=Miriam: Yes to divorce law, no to abortion|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News]]|date=December 20, 2012|access-date=March 30, 2018}} On contraception, she stressed the importance of its distribution, especially in poverty-stricken areas. She was a strong proponent of the Philippines' [[Reproductive Health Law]], which guarantees universal access to methods on contraception, maternal health and [[sex education]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/88686-miriam-reflections-god-religion|last=Macaraig|first=Ayee|title=Miriam on God, hell and the middle finger|work=[[Rappler]]|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=7 August 2016}} According to her, the bill was shelved for more than 13 years, citing the [[Catholic Church in the Philippines|Catholic Church]]'s opposition.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/18730-rh-law-the-long-and-rough-road|title=RH law: The long and rough road|author=Fonbuena, Carmela |work=[[Rappler]]|accessdate=8 September 2016}} Defensor Santiago expressed dismay when the RH Law had suffered a one-billion peso budget cut before the [[Congress of the Philippines|Congress]] in early 2016. She said if she will be elected, she will work for a full and conscientious implementation of the law.{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/01/09/1540764/senators-slam-rh-budget-cut|title=Senators slam RH budget cut|author=Sy, Marvin|website=Philstar.com|accessdate=8 September 2016}} ====LGBT rights==== Defensor Santiago magnified the issues concerning the LGBT community before the Senate. In the wake of the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]] incident, she said on a Twitter post: "The mass shooting at a club in Orlando is appalling and heartbreaking" and "I long for the day when the LGBT community no longer has to live in fear of discrimination and hate crimes".{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/06/13/1592548/senators-express-shock-over-orlando-mass-shooting|title=Senators express shock over Orlando mass shooting|author=Viray, Patricia Lourdes|accessdate=8 September 2016}} Defensor Santiago was one of the senators who advocated the immediate investigation of [[Death of Jennifer Laude|the Jennifer Laude case]], wherein the American marine, Joseph Scott Pemberton, killed Laude, a Filipina [[transgender]], in Subic, Zambales. She also supported the passage of the anti-discrimination bill ([[SOGIE Equality Bill]]) which protects the rights of people of different sexual orientation, gender identity, and expression. She was the first senator in Philippine history to push for the bill's legislation, filing it repeatedly since 2000.{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/72528-miriam-barbie-senate-probe|title=Miriam wants 'Barbie' in Senate probe on Laude death|author=Fonbuena, Carmela|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=8 September 2016}} ====Capital punishment==== Defensor Santiago favored the [[capital punishment|death penalty]] but limited it to heinous crimes, while maintaining that the justice system should be improved.{{cite news|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/03/20/Pilipinas-Debates-2016-Santiago-Duterte-Poe-Binay-Roxas.html|title=Despite absence, Defensor Santiago makes presence felt through social media|website=CNN Philippines|accessdate=8 September 2016}} ====Environment==== Defensor Santiago vehemently opposed mining. She believes mining is one of the greatest reasons why local communities are impoverished as most of the profit coming from mining are siphoned by mining companies away from the local economy. In addition, mining has made numerous destructive advances in Philippine society and ecosystems, destroying watersheds and agricultural lands, as well as rivers and seas. According to an interview conducted by [[Haribon Foundation]] during the 2016 Presidential Campaign, the organization voted her as the "greenest" in all of the candidates. She was the main author of the Climate Change Law and the Renewable Energies Law in the Senate.{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/04/19/1574455/miriam-greenest-mar-meanest-environmentalists|title=Miriam 'greenest', Mar 'meanest' for environmentalists|author=Dumlao, Artemio|website=Philstar.com|date=19 April 2016|accessdate=8 September 2016}} ====Internet==== Defensor Santiago advocated the establishment of the Department of Information which is mandated to speed-up internet connectivity in the Philippines which she described "the worst internet speed in Asia". She also advocated for the passage of the Magna Carta for Philippine Internet Freedom which protects the rights and freedoms of Filipinos in cyberspace, while defining and penalizing [[cybercrime]]s.{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2013/07/03/961171/its-miriams-internet-freedom-bill-vs-anti-cybercrime-law |title=It's Miriam's Internet Freedom bill vs Anti-Cybercrime Law |author=Bacani, Louis|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=8 September 2016}} ====Transportation==== Defensor Santiago advocated the establishment of a completely new railway system from Manila to Sorsogon and a new high-speed transit system connecting Metro Manila to Pampanga, Bulacan. Rizal, Batangas, Laguna, and Cavite. She also advocated the establishment of a new modernized airport and the establishment of new projects in every province in the entire country.{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/124277-miriam-santiago-public-infrastructure|title=Modern airport, train systems: Miriam vows better public infra|website=Rappler|date=1 March 2016|accessdate=8 September 2016}} ==Awards and honors== * [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] for Government Service, 1988, Asian equivalent of the Nobel Prize, Magsaysay Awards Foundation * TOYM Award Bulletin|work=mb.com.ph|accessdate=15 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160408004419/http://www.mb.com.ph/miriam-inducted-to-hall-of-fame-of-ph-judges/|archivedate=8 April 2016|df=dmy-all}} * Most Outstanding Alumna in Law, University of the Philippines, 1988 * Gold Vision Triangle Award for government service, 1988, YMCA Philippines * Republic Anniversary Award for law enforcement, 1988, Civic Assembly of Women of the Philippines * Golden Jubilee Achievement Award for public service, 1990, Girl Scouts of the Philippines * Celebrity Mother Award, 1991, de la Orden del Mérito Civil a los señores que se citan|url=http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2007/12/01/pdfs/A49782-49782.pdf|publisher=Boletín Oficial del Estado (BOE)|accessdate=27 November 2015}} * Distinguished Icon of Legal Excellence and Public Service Award (2 September 2016) * PUP Online Personality of the Year 2016 *[[Quezon Service Cross]], (3 December 2018, Posthumous) ==Writings== Defensor Santiago wrote at least 30 books, many of which are about law and social sciences. Among her works is the ''Code Annotated Series Project 2000'', a series of books about laws passed by the Philippine Congress and Supreme Court decisions. The ''Code Annotated Series'' is the main part of Defensor Santiago's Legal Outreach Program.{{cite news|title=Santiago has 2 new law books|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QFM1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZyUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1374%2C2109322|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=3 April 2000}} During her initial battle with cancer, she continued to work on the 2014 edition of all her law books. These were published as the 2015 edition of her ''Code Annotated Series'', by Rex Bookstore.{{cite web|url=http://www.rexestore.com/law-textbooks/1339-rules-of-court-annotated-vol-ii-pb.html?search_query=miriam+defensor+santiago&results=24|title=Rules of Court Annotated Vol. II (PB)|work=Rex e-Store|accessdate=15 April 2016}} The doctoral dissertation she wrote for the [[University of Michigan]] was published as a book, ''Political Offences in International Law''.{{cite web|title=Judge Miriam DEFENSOR-SANTIAGO (Philippines)|url=https://www.icc-cpi.int/en_menus/icc/structure%20of%20the%20court/chambers/the%20judges/Pages/judge%20miriam%20defensor_santiago%20_philippines_.aspx|publisher=International Criminal Court|accessdate=10 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925220701/http://www.icc-cpi.int/en_menus/icc/structure%20of%20the%20court/chambers/the%20judges/Pages/judge%20miriam%20defensor_santiago%20_philippines_.aspx|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} She wrote two autobiographies, ''Inventing Myself'' {{cite book|last=Defensor Santiago|first=Miriam|title=Inventing Myself|publisher=New Day Publishers of the Christian Literature Society of the Philippines, Inc.|date=1994|isbn=971-10-0552-2}} and ''Cutting Edge: The Politics of Reform in the Philippines,'' the latter being praised by UK Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]].{{cite book|last=Defensor Santiago|first=Miriam|title=Cutting Edge: The Politics of Reform in the Philippines|publisher=Woman Today Publications|date=1994|isbn=971-49-0003-4}} She published a joke book in 2014, ''Stupid is Forever'', a collection of jokes, comebacks, one-liners, and pick-up lines she used in speeches.{{cite news|title=Miriam: 'I've heard millions of stupid things in the Senate'|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/76889-miriam-santiago-book-stupid-forever|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=3 December 2014}} A sequel, titled ''[[Stupid is Forevermore]]'', was published a year later. Both books were published by ABS-CBN Publishing.{{cite news|title=Miriam launches new humor book on 70th birthday|url=http://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Weekender&title=The-wit-and-humor-of-Miriam-Defensor-Santiago&id=110314|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=15 June 2015}} The first book was named the best-selling book of 2014, selling about 110,000 copies in one month.{{cite news|title=Sen. Miriam's 'stupid' book now a bestseller|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2015/01/25/1416403/sen.-miriams-stupid-book-now-bestseller|website=GMA News|accessdate=10 February 2016}} ==Personal life== Defensor Santiago grew up in a middle-class erudite household with both parents having higher educational attainments. She is the eldest among her siblings: Benjamin, Nenalyn, Linn, and Paula Dimpna Beatriz.{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/news/10/02/16/watch-miriams-sister-thanks-god-family-fans |title=WATCH: Miriam's sister thanks God, family, fans |work=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]] |date=October 2, 2016 |accessdate=October 2, 2016}} She was married to Narciso "Jun" Santiago Jr.,{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/halalan2016/focus/05/04/16/narciso-jun-santiago-miriams-shock-absorber|last=Alberto-Masakayan|first=Theas|title=Narciso 'Jun' Santiago, Miriam's shock absorber|work=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=4 May 2016|accessdate=7 August 2016}} with whom she had two sons, Narciso III (Archie) and Alexander (A.R.); Alexander committed suicide in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/228820/%C2%91miriam-son-suicide%C2%92|title=Miriam son a suicide|work=''[[The Philippine Star|Philstar.com]]''|date=22 November 2003|accessdate=7 August 2016}} The couple adopted four children; Megan Santiago, Mallory Santiago, Mackenzie Santiago, and Morven Santiago.{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/people-people/595336/miriam-defensor-santiago-motherhood-also-becomes-her |title=Miriam Defensor Santiago: Motherhood also becomes her |author=Roco, Denise |website=Philstar.com |date=July 22, 2010 |accessdate=October 1, 2016}} She and her husband renewed their wedding vows on their 40th wedding anniversary in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/06/20/11/miriam-backs-divorce-bill-renews-vows|title=Miriam backs divorce bill, renews wedding vows|publisher=abs-cbn.com|accessdate=29 September 2016}} She has close relationships with actress and visual artist, [[Heart Evangelista]], who she has mentored.https://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/09/29/16/heart-thanks-miriam-for-showing-her-so-much-of-the-world ===Religious views=== In an interview with ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' years after the death of her son who committed suicide, she said:{{Quote|text=The only thing I know about God is that God is inscrutable. In other words, I don't know a single thing about God. I'm clueless about what God is. Maybe Jesus, or the other historical figures around which religions had been built, would be more approachable. But God itself, being on a divine level, I think it's just impermeable to human intelligence. And there is a very famous classical book called ''[[The Cloud of Unknowing]]''. There's always a cloud of unknowing over God. I think that, since God is inaccessible to people, we tend to portray Him in anthropomorphic terms. We think of the best qualities in every person and you try and project it on a giant scale on God. So in effect, God is a man-made concept. We have no clue what God is.{{cite news|url=http://www.esquiremagazine.ph/culture/miriam-defensor-santiago-is-not-insane|title=Miriam Defensor Santiago is not insane|author=Romulo, Erwin T.|work=Esquire|date=13 December 2011|accessdate=8 September 2016}}}} She stated in a separate interview:{{Quote|text=I do not understand why God can be all love and still inflict this kind of pain on people. This God is an underachiever. He does not do whatever he is supposed to be doing, whatever his sex is. Whether he's an it or a she or a he or whatever. But I'm sure that if you were a god or if I were the God, I would be doing a better job. Therefore, the only conclusion can be that possibly, God does not exist.}} In the succeeding years, Defensor Santiago returned to her faith. She was quoted as saying, "Good things happen to those who love God." Notwithstanding her defense of the [[Reproductive Health Law]], a law that has been opposed by the [[Catholic Church in the Philippines]],{{cite news|last1=Alave|first1=Kristine L. |last2=Burgonio |first2=TJ |title=Massive Church rally set against RH bill|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/241737/massive-church-rally-set-against-rh-bill|accessdate=7 January 2017|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=August 3, 2012}} she asserted her [[Catholicism]]{{cite book|last1=Defensor Santiago|first1=Miriam|title=[[Stupid is Forever]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Publishing]]|isbn=978-971-816-127-2|page=14|quote=I sponsored and defended the Reproductive Health Law, although I am a Catholic. In the Catholic church, a woman to avoid a pregnancy is allowed to resort to mathematics. Thank God, now Catholic women are allowed to resort to physics and chemistry!}} and remained religious as an adult, saying her prayers day and night.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2016/05/03/1579094/body-talk-miriam-defensor-santiago|last=Lo|first=Ricky|title=Body Talk with Miriam Defensor-Santiago|website=Philstar.com|date=3 May |url=https://www.dailypioneer.com/columnists/edit/is-and-its-disastrous-influence-in-afghanistan.html |title=IS and its disastrous influence in Afghanistan |author=Jai Kumar |work=[[The Pioneer (newspaper)|The Pioneer]] |date=4 April 2018 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref> is an Afghan militant and [[Salafi movement|Salafist]] cleric who served as a field commander for the [[Taliban]] and later the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]]'s [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Khorasan Province|Khorasan Province]] (ISIL-K) in northern [[Afghanistan]], particularly [[Jowzjan Province]]. While waging an insurgency against the Afghan government, he has been accused of committing several war crimes.
== Biography == === Early life and service with the Taliban === [[File:Flag of Taliban.svg|thumb|left|Nemat initially was a field commander of the [[Taliban]] (flag pictured), but was expelled from the movement in 2014.<ref name="pashtun"/> ]]
An ethnic [[Uzbeks|Uzbek]],<ref name="pashtun">{{cite web |url=https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/non-pashtun-taleban-of-the-north-4-a-case-study-from-jawzjan/ |title=Non-Pashtun Taleban of the North (4): A case study from Jawzjan |author=Obaid Ali |work=[[Afghanistan Analysts Network]] |date=18 September 2017 |accessdate=25 August 2018 }}</ref> Nemat originally was a religious teacher<ref name="Aided">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/28/world/asia/isis-northern-afghanistan.html |title=ISIS, Aided by Ex-Taliban Groups, Makes Inroads in Northern Afghanistan |author1=Jawad Sukhanyar |author2=Rod Nordland |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=28 June 2017 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref> and [[mufti]]<ref name="rape">{{cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/is-commander-accused-of-rape-surrenders-to-authoritie/4516044.html |title=Islamic State Commander Accused of Rape Surrenders |author=Mohammad Habibzada |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=6 August 2018 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref> in [[Vice President of Afghanistan|First Vice President]] [[Abdul Rashid Dostum]]'s home village in [[Jowzjan Province]].<ref name="Aided"/> At some point, Nemat became a [[Salafi movement|Salafist]]<ref name="pashtun"/> and joined the [[Taliban]],<ref name="Aided"/> forming a small [[private army]] to fight for [[Qush Tepa District]]. He eventually rose to head of the Taliban military committee for the districts of [[Darzab District|Darzab]] and Qush Tepa in Jowzjan,<ref name="pashtun"/> and was considered to be an "important" field commander for the insurgents.<ref name="disastrous"/> It is possible that Nemat took part in "Operation Badr", a major Taliban offensive in northern Afghanistan in 2011.{{efn|Afghan authorities claimed that "Mawlawi Nematullah", one of "two top Taliban leaders for Jawzjan", fought at the village of al Malik in Qush Tepa from 9 and 11 April 2011. The provincial authorities argued that the man in question was killed in the fighting, but Afghan government claims about Taliban deaths are often unreliable.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2011/08/operation_badr_track.php |title=Operation Badr: tracking the Taliban summer offensive in Jawzjan province |author=Matt Dupee |work=[[Long War Journal]] |date=17 August 2011 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref> }} According to [[Pajhwok Afghan News]], he even served as shadow governor of Jowzjan at some point, and was adressed with the honorific title "[[Mawlawi (Islamic title)|Maulvi]]".<ref name="more peace">{{cite web |url=http://dev.pajhwok.com/en/2015/03/10/more-jawzjan-militants-join-peace-process |title=More Jawzjan militants join peace process |author=Tamkin |work=[[Pajhwok Afghan News]] |date=30 December 2014 |accessdate=27 November 2018 }}</ref> Despite this, Nemat was also increasingly criticised by his superiors for various irregularities, including abuse of authority, harassment and torture of locals over taxation, and corruption. While visiting [[Pakistan]] in 2013, Nemat was arrested by the Taliban over these issues, and expelled from the rebel movement in 2014.<ref name="pashtun"/><ref name="more peace"/>
In response, Nemat made a deal with Vice President Dostum<ref name="pashtun"/> in December 2014,<ref name="more peace"/> and officially surrendered to the Afghan government with 220<ref name="rape"/> of his followers in February 2015.<ref name="precarious">{{cite web |url=https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/precarious-consolidation-qari-hekmats-is-affiliated-island-survives-another-taleban-onslaught/ |title=Precarious Consolidation: Qari Hekmat’s IS-affiliated 'island' survives another Taleban onslaught |author=Obaid Ali |work=[[Afghanistan Analysts Network]] |date=4 March 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://thediplomat.com/2015/04/working-with-general-abdul-rashid-dostum/ |title=Working With General Abdul Rashid Dostum |author=Sultan Faizy |work=[[The Diplomat]] |date=24 April 2018 |accessdate=27 November 2018 }}</ref> He and his fighters were promised salaries for six months, and help in finding new civilian jobs.<ref name="more peace"/> For the next two years, he stayed in [[Sheberghan]], hoping to gain an appointment as commander in the pro-government militias. Nemat also started a [[Salafi movement|Salafi]] [[madrasa]] called ''E'ya-ye Sunnat'' ("Rehabilitation of the [[Sunnah]]"), and organized classes for male and female students. His Salafist views aroused great opposition from the local religious establishment of [[Hanafi]] clerics, resulting in several public debates between Nemat and a number of his opponents. State authorities eventually shut down his madrasa and banned him from teaching in Jowzjan Province in November 2016.<ref name="pashtun"/> Believing that neither Dostum nor the rest of government had upheld their part of the agreement with him,<ref name="Aided"/> Nemat consequently resumed his insurgency. He joined forces with [[Qari Hekmat]], the leader of the region's branch of [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Khorasan Province|ISIL's Khorasan Province]].<ref name="pashtun"/><ref name="Aided"/> Though Nemat later argued that his decision to join ISIL-K stemmed from [[Ideology of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ideological conviction]],<ref name="guests">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/04/world/asia/islamic-state-prisoners-afghanistan.html |title=Are ISIS Fighters Prisoners or Honored Guests of the Afghan Government? |author1=Najim Rahim |author2=Rod Nordland |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=4 August 2018 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref> an expert of the ''[[Afghanistan Analysts Network]]'' said that he had probably been more motivated by "power-saving opportunism".<ref name="pashtun"/>
=== ISIL-K commander === Commanding about 80 fighters, Nemat became the commander for all ISIL-K forces in Darzab's Sar Dara area, and was also appointed by Hekmat as head of ISIL-K's local military court.<ref name="precarious"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mackenzieinstitute.com/mixtrac-islamic-state-targets-foreigners-tajikistan-increased-activity-afghanistan/ |title=MIxTRAC: Islamic State Targets Foreigners in Tajikistan and Increased Activity in Afghanistan |author= |work=[[Mackenzie Institute]]; [[Terrorism Research & Analysis Consortium]] |date=7 August 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018 }}</ref> In course of 2017, ISIL-K grew increasingly powerful in northern Afghanistan, and almost [[Battle of Darzab (2017)|completely captured Darzab District]] from the Taliban and government forces, including Dostum's militias, in April.<ref name="precarious"/><ref name="still">{{cite web |url=https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/still-under-the-iss-black-flag-qari-hekmats-iskp-island-in-jawzjan-after-his-death-by-drone/ |title=Still under the IS's Black Flag: Qari Hekmat's ISKP island in Jawzjan after his death by drone |author=Obaid Ali |work=[[Afghanistan Analysts Network]] |date=15 May 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018 }}</ref> At the time, government officials regarded Nemat as one of the most important Islamic State commanders, stating that "he knows the Darzab District and the area very well; he is a very dangerous guy".<ref name="Aided"/> Darzab consequently became the group's stronghold, though it repeatedly attempted to expand into other areas.<ref name="precarious"/><ref name="still"/> Hekmat was killed by a US airstrike in April 2018, and the other northern ISIL-K commanders consequently elected Mawlavi Habibul Rahman,<ref name="still"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2018/04/us-military-kills-senior-islamic-state-commander-in-afghan-north.php |title=US military kills senior Islamic State commander in Afghan north |author=Bill Roggio |work=[[Long War Journal]] |date=9 April 2018 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref> Nemat's brother-in-law, as their new leader.<ref name="surge"/><ref name="still"/> An expert speculated that Nemat might have played an important role in the succession;<ref name="still"/> in any case, he became ISIL-K's second-in-command for Jowzjan Province after Mawlavi Habibul Rahman's appointment.<ref name="rape"/> While serving with ISIL-K, Nemat reportedly committed numerous war crimes.<ref name="rape"/>
==== Surrender ==== [[File:More Than 240 IS Militants Surrender to Afghan Government Forces.webm|thumb|right|''[[Voice of America]]'' report about the surrender, including an interview with Mufti Nemat ]]
Despite their military successes in 2017, ISIL-K remained threatened by the Taliban in northern Afghanistan, as the latter repeatedly attempted to oust the Islamic State militants from Darzab. A major [[Battle of Darzab (2018)|Taliban offensive in July 2018]] eventually overwhelmed ISIL-K's defenses and brought the group's northern branch to the brink of destruction. The Taliban rejected offers for a ceasefire, and demanded that Nemat, alongside Mawlavi Habibul Rahman and Sibghatullah, ISIL-K's local head of finances be handed over to them. At this point, the northern ISIL-K branch split, with a substantial number of fighters defecting to the Taliban, while the three commanders and their loyalists decided to contact the Afghan government and offered their surrender in exchange for protection from the Taliban.<ref name="island">{{cite web |url=https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/qari-hekmats-island-overrun-taleban-defeat-iskp-in-jawzjan/ |title=Qari Hekmat's Island Overrun: Taleban defeat 'ISKP' in Jawzjan |author=Obaid Ali |work=[[Afghanistan Analysts Network]] |date=4 August 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018 }}</ref> Nemat and his fellow fighters, along with their families, consequently fled to government lines in the night, protected by [[Commandos (Afghanistan)|Commandos]] and the [[Afghan Air Force]].<ref name="surge"/><ref name="guests"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2018/08/taliban-says-islamic-state-is-completely-defeated-in-jawzjan.php |title=Taliban says Islamic State has been 'completely defeated' in Jawzjan |author=Bill Roggio |work=[[Long War Journal]] |date=1 August 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/is-fighters-surrender-to-afghan-forces-after-taliban-assault/4508748.html |title=IS Fighters Surrender to Afghan Forces After Taliban Assault |author=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=1 August 2018 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref>
Following his surrender, the ISIL-K militants were transported to [[Sheberghan]], where they were treated rather well despite the protests of many local civilians and soldiers. Nemat subsequently gave several interviews to the press, declaring that "[[fake news]]" were responsible for the Islamic State's bad reputation. He claimed that he and his followers had only launched an insurgency because they were met with hostility by the "whole world", and that he wanted people to accept ISIL's ideology "with their hearts, not by force". Regarding his future, Nemat said that the "Afghan government must save my life and provide me with security" as it promised to do so before the surrender, and that he was not guilty of any crimes.<ref name="guests"/> Despite these claims, several women had previously accused him of having abducted and raped them. This was notable, as it was "the first time Afghan women have come forward and accused IS fighters of rape". [[Rape in Afghanistan|Rape victims in Afghanistan]] usually do not speak out due to rape being a taboo topic in the country's society.<ref name="rape"/> Other civilians accused ISIL-K of having executed over one hundred civilians, including children, and of practising slavery in Darzab.<ref name="guests"/> The government was widely criticised for "its unexplained action of providing asylum and protection to IS-K militants", prompting officials to declare that the Islamic State fighters would be brought to justice.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/afghan-government-under-fire-for-rescuing-islamic-state-militants/4515574.html |title=Afghan Government Under Fire for Rescuing Islamic State Militants |author=Ayaz Gul |work=[[Voice of America]] |date=6 August 2018 |accessdate=13 August 2018 }}</ref>

{{Merge from|Dwadashaakshar|date=October 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Vaishnavism}} [[File:Avatars of Vishnu.jpg|thumb|"Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya" is a Mantra of [[Krishna]].]] '''Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya''' ({{audio|Om_Namo_Bhavate_Vasudevaya_Pronunciation.ogg|listen}}) (in [[devanagari]]: ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय) is one of the most popular [[Hindu]] [[mantra]] and the most important mantra in [[Vaishnavism]]. It is called as '''Dwadasakshari Mantra''' or simply '''Dwadasakshari''' meaning the "twelve-syllable" mantra dedicated to Lord Krishna/Vishnu.{{cite book|title=Bhāratīya Saṃskr̥ti, Volume 1|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=qa8aAAAAMAAJ|author=Prabhakar Balvant Machwe|publisher=Bhāratīya Saṃskr̥ti Saṃsada|page=212|year=1983}}{{cite book|title=Krishna: A Sourcebook|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=2n4VDAAAQBAJ|author=Edwin F. Bryant|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=354|accessdate=18 June 2007}} It has two traditions—[[Tantra|Tantric]] and [[Puranic]]. In Tantrik Tradition, the Rishi of the Mantra is [[Prajapati]], in Puranic Tradition the Rishi is [[Narada]]. Both, however, say it is the Supreme Vishnu Mantra. Sharada Tilak Tantram says: {{cquote|"Dvadasharno mahamantrah pradhano Vaishnavagame"— '''Meaning''': the twelve lettered mantra is the chief among vaishnava mantras.}} Similarly, this is the ultimate mantra in [[Shrimad Bhagavatam]]. This twelve syllable mantra{{cite book|author=Alexander Studholme|title=The Origins of Oṃ Maṇipadme Hūṃ: A Study of the Kāraṇḍavyūha Sūtra|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5VlulOGhZ3EC&pg=PA177|accessdate=24 June 2012|year=2002|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-5389-6|pages=177}} is known as a Mukti (liberation) mantra and a spiritual formula for attaining freedom.{{cite web|title=Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya|url=http://spiritualsoul.net/group/mantra/forum/topics/om-namo-bhagavate-vasudevaya?xg_source=activity|accessdate=14 April 2012}} This mantra can also be found in [[Vishnu Purana]]. ==Meaning== ''Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya'' means "''Om'', I bow to Lord Vasudeva or Lord Krishna".{{cite book|author=J. Donald Walters|title=The Art and Science of Raja Yoga: Fourteen Steps to Higher Awareness : Based on the Teachings of Paramhansa Yogananda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zh9DJU6CvLAC&pg=PA251|accessdate=24 June 2012|date=1 March 2002|publisher=Crystal Clarity Publishers|isbn=978-1-56589-166-1|pages=251–}} [[File:Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya in Devanagari.png|thumb|Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya in [[Devnagari]], this Mantra is used for invocation and dedication to Krishna]] {| class="wikitable" width="60%" |- bgcolor="#C2D4F2" !Term!!Devanagari!!Listen!!Meaning |- |[[Om]]'''||

||{{audio|Vasudevaya_Pronunciation.ogg|Vasudevaya}}||Name of Krishna, Krishna is also known as Vaasudeva (Krishna), because he was the son of [[Vasudeva]]. In the [[Bhagavad-Gita]], [[Arjuna]] called Krishna by the name Vaasudeva multiple times. 'Vāsudevāya' वासुदेवाय is the [[dative case|dative]] of 'vāsudeva' वासुदेव. Other meaning for Vasudevaya is Vasu means "Life in all beings" Devaya means "God". This means God(life/light) who lives of all beings. |} ==Importance== ''Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya'' means "prostration to Vasudeva" who is variously understood as Krishna or Vishnu."{{cite web|title=The Significance of Mantra-Japa Sadhana|url=http://www.swami-krishnananda.org/disc/disc_90.html|publisher=swami-krishnananda.org|accessdate=14 April 2012|author=Swami Krishnananda}} Krishna himself asked his devotees to completely surrender to him: {{cquote|सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं शरणं व्रज । अहं त्वां सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा शुचः ॥१८- ६६॥
'''Translation''' Abandon all varieties of religion and just surrender unto Me. I shall deliver you from all sinful reaction. Do not fear. [Gita 18/66]}} Krishna also proclaimed "Everybody should recite "Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya" mantra daily whenever possible so that I will stand by them. I respond to the call of the heart immediately and invariably. See me in your duties. I am committed to those who are committed to their duties. Believe in putting faith in me and make me your own".{{cite web|title=Autobiography Of Parampoojya Leelavati Karve|url=http://www.yogeshwar.org/om.htm|publisher=yogeshwar.org/|accessdate=4 May 2012}} ==Popular culture== *[[Dhruva]] used this as his mantra in his penance.
